column1: '''James Branch Cabell''' ([[14 April]] [[1879]] â€“ [[5 May]] [[1958]]) was an American author of science-fiction and belles lettres.
[[Arne Zettersten]] remembers sending [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] a newspaper article which suggested that Tolkien had been influenced by Cabell:<ref>Arne Zettersten
column2: ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien's Double Worlds and Creative Process]]''

column1: {{blockquote|Tolkien wrote back to me and denied forcefully that this was true. The next time we met he took up the matter again and maintained that he knew Cabell well
column2: but that he had read only one of his books and that it was 'quite boring'.}}

column1: The anthology ''[[The Young Magicians]]'' ([[1969]]) edited by [[Lin Carter]]
column2: to which Tolkien contributed with two poems
column3: also includes Cabell's "The Way of Ecben".

column2: editor [[Douglas A. Anderson]] includes Cabell's short story "The Thin Queen of Elfhame". Anderson writes that "Cabell represents a very different type of fantasy from Tolkien"
column3: the former often including irony in his writings.<ref>[[Douglas A. Anderson]]
